Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports the Doctoral Colloquium program at the 2010 iConference to be held on the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign February 3 - February 6, 2010. This workshop will bring together 15 dissertation-stage doctoral students from diverse information and informatics subfields for one day of presentations, interaction, and feedback with 5 faculty members selected from among distinguished information researchers. The iConference Doctoral Research Colloquium is designed to assist doctoral students to become stewards of the information and informatics disciplines, by providing an opportunity for interaction with distinguished research faculty and for the development of a global cohort of new researchers. This award provides support for the travel, lodging and registration of students, plus one night lodging for the participating faculty mentors, as well as the direct expenses of putting on the Doctoral Colloquium at the meeting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The iConference Doctoral Research Colloquium (DC) was intended to help new researchers address the challenges and opportunities of interdisciplinarity, and what these imply for undertaking research, collaborating, publishing, explaining one’s work to diverse audiences, and situating oneself within organizations and departments. Distinguished research faculty were invited to participate in the DC on the basis of their reputation in the field and their reputation for the effective nurturing of fledgling researchers. We began with an overview of the DC, emphasizing its supportive approach, encouraging the airing of issues that are sometimes hard to air in one’s home department. We then did a ‘Just a minute elevator pitch’ icebreaker for attendees and mentors.

Students were put into one of 5 groups based on their research area to work with a mentor. Each student did a short 10 minute talk and then got 10 minutes or so of feedback and Q&A, both from the mentor and the fellow students. This activity was repeated in the afternoon. Each student got a new mentor, never had to sit through the talk of any given student twice, and each time got a mentor at least partially associated with their area. The point of the repetition was to enable a multiplicity of perspectives, and also for students to practice and refine the act of presenting. Immediately after presenting, it is common to realize that one could have put across one’s thinking better. But normally it is several weeks before the opportunity arises to present the research again. This way we were able to condense the learning into a day.

Two plenary sessions on airing worries and concerns showed how a named concern can be addressed by multiple strategies. Faculty mentors were very honest about how they struggle when they tackle a difficult research problem. It is important for students to understand the struggles, messiness and compromise, because these are mostly painted out of research papers which typically present a very tidied up view of the research process, that is so unlike the students’ experience of her own processes that she can believe she is doing it all wrong.

Participants could take part in optional video interviews where the student explained the nature and relevance of their research, run as a conversation with the DC organizer and aimed at a very general audience. The videos were intended to address a number of issues:

  • It is good to practice being interviewed. We are increasingly being called upon to make our research accessible to wider audiences, including the taxpayers who fund it.
  • New media create new opportunities (and maybe soon requirements) to present our work and ourselves this way as well as the traditional methods of text and public presentation.
  • Conferences and other talks are increasing being videoed and archived. There is no escaping from it, so it is as well to learn how to do it well.
  • So much of being a researcher is about presenting the results. Watching a video of your attempts to explain difficult concepts can help you think about how to do it better. Surely this should be a classic engineering optimization challenge. How do you maximize the understanding of your audience?
  • One theme that pervaded the day was the challenge of speaking to a very diverse audience. A classic (but not unique) case is doing a job talk. You want to show off how clever you are - to the 5 people in the audience who understand your research and even go to the same disciplinary conference as you. But what about the rest of your audience? They are all very smart people, but many - perhaps most, will come from a completely different disciplinary, methodological and epistemological tradition. Can you explain to them at least why your research matters...
